areaDesc.2: Principal subdivisions are known as Peacock Woods (A-1); Dinglewood (A-2); best portion of Woodcrest (A-3); and best portion of Overlook (A-4). A-4 is outside of city limits. Land is rolling in all areas except A-4, which is practically level.
areaDesc.3: Lots are nicely landscaped, all streets paved except in A-4. A-1 has extremely large lots with rigid building restrictions, while the other areas have good good-sized lots and good building restrictions. All areas except A-4 are conveniently located to schools parks and have good bus transportation facilities. All utilities are in all areas and all are conveniently located to community business section.
areaDesc.4: A-4 is inconveniently located to schools and bus transportation.

5.a: Executives, retired business men and professional men

areaDesc.14: A-1 is exclusive residential section. A-1 contains about 15 houses, A-2 about 5, A-3 about 10, and A-4 about 10 making a total of approximately 40 houses in these four areas. In A-4 on the south side of Edgewood Drive, between Benning Boulevard and Brookwood Avenue, are located one or two properties whose repair condition entitles them to C grade rating.

15.1: Mr. H. Lend, of Land Realty Company, and Mr. Henry F. Boyce, of Boyce Realty Company, who is also president of the Columbus Real Estate Broad

areaDesc.2: Principal subdivisions are Rock Park, Wynnton Heights, and Boulevard Terrace (B-1); Wildwood Circle and remaining portion Woodcrest (B-3); Wynnton south of Macon Road, Oakview, and remaining portion of Overlook (B-2); Weracoba Heights (B-4); St. Elmo (B-5); Cherokee heights (B-6). Land is these areas is rolling and hilly, except in B-2) and B-5, where the land is level and sloping.
areaDesc.3: All public utilities in. About 60% of streets paved. All areas zoned and restricted. Proximity of the areas to schools, parks, play-grounds, and community business centers. All areas except B-3 and B-6 have adequate bus transportaion.
areaDesc.4: B-6 is adversely affected because of distance from schools, churches, buses, and community centers.
areaDesc.14: B-1 has about 40 houses; B-2 about 50; B-3 about 50; B-4 about 100; B-5 about 150; B-6 about 10, aming a total of approximately 400 houses in tehse 6 areas. Jumping of a color grade along the southwestern boundary of B-2 (Blue to red) is explained by the fact taht this portion of B-2 is on this top of a high hill which drops off abruptly to the adjoining negro property (d-4) below the crest of the hill. There is one large multiple unil apartment house in B-3. In the southeastern section of B-2, along both sides of Buena Vista Road, beginning at Brown Avenue and extending about 2 blocks west, are a group of properties whose poor repair condition places same in the D classification, instead of B as shown by the map; also in this same area on the northeast corner of Edgewood Drive and Benning Boulevard are one or two large properties which should be classified as C grade property. In B-3 from 16th to 17th Street east of Wildwood Avenue, are several large old properties which should be classified as C grade property

areaDesc.2: Principal subdivision is the best residential section of Old City. The land si practically level.
areaDesc.3: About 95% of the streets are paved. Good schools, churches, and bus transportation. All utilities in. Proximity to main business district.
areaDesc.4: Encroachment of business. Heavy traffic conditions. Boarding houses in the area. Advanced age of properties.

5.a: Clerical workers and retired business poeple (Some of city's oldest families)

areaDesc.14: (a) Due to doubling process, lenders will lend in this area. (b) Only local individual

15.1: Mr. H. Land, of Land Realty Company, and Mr. Harry F. Boyce, of the Boyce Realty Company, who is also president of the Columbus Real Estate Board

areaDesc.2: Principal subdivisions are known as Peacock Woods (A-1); Dinglewood (A-2); best portion of Woodcrest (A-3); and best portion of Overlook (A-4). A-4 is outside of city limits. Land is rolling in all areas except A-4, which is practically level.
areaDesc.3: Lots are nicely landscaped, all streets paved except in A-4. A-1 has extremely large lots with rigid building restrictions, while the other areas have good good-sized lots and good building restrictions. All areas except A-4 are conveniently located to schools parks and have good bus transportation facilities. areaDesc.4: A-4 is inconveniently located to schools and bus transportation.

5.a: Executives, retired business men and professional men

areaDesc.14: A-1 is exclusive residential section. A-1 contains about 15 houses, A-2 about 5, A-3 about 10, and A-4 about 10 making a total of approximately 40 houses in these four areas. In A-4 on the south side of Edgewood Drive, between Benning Boulevard and Brookwood Avenue, are located one or two properties whose repair condition entitles them to C grade rating.

15.1: Mr. H. Lend, of Land Realty Company, and Mr. Henry F. Boyce, of Boyce Realty Company, who is also president of the Columbus Real Estate Broad

areaDesc.2: Principal subdivisions are Brookhaven (C-8); Andrews Woods, Andrews Survey, and Benning Park (C-9). The land in these Areas is mostly level. Both areas are outside of city limits.
areaDesc.3: Electricity and city water in all except Benning Park and Andrews Survey.
areaDesc.4: Only street is State Highway, which traverses the area. Distance from city, along with inadequate bus transportation, schools and churches. No gas. Restrictions virtually disregarded. Surface toilets in all except Andrews Woods. Proximity to fertilizer and meat packing plants.
areaDesc.13: Stable as long as new building continues, then downward.
areaDesc.14: About 50% of the occupants of these areas are Army people. (A) Due to the fact that all of the 20 houses in C-8 have been built in the past 18 months. Much of 0-9 is unimproved. There is come Negro property located along the northeast side of Cusseta Road and east side of Lumpkin Road which should carry a D grade rating.

15.1: Mr. H. Land, of Land Realty Company, and Mr. Harry F. Boyce, of the Boyce Realty Company, who is also president of the Columbus Real Estate Board

areaDesc.2: These areas contain portions of Old South Commons (D-1); eastern portion of Rosehill, western portion of East Highlands and Jordan City (D-3); Bottoms (D-4); Land is rolling except in D-1, where it is level.
areaDesc.3: Proximity to churches and schools. Adequate bus transportation for Negroes. Electricity and water in all areas.
areaDesc.4: No zoning, building restrictions, or sewerage. Only about 3% of streets paved (thoroughfares which traverse the area). Vandalism present. Obnoxious odors in D-1. Portion of D-4 subject to overflow after heavy rains. Portions of D-1, 4, and 5 outside of city have no fire portection.
areaDesc.13: Downward D-1 and 3; static for Negroes in D-4 and 5.
areaDesc.14: (a) Only local individual lenders will lend in these areas. In D-1 on the sides of Broadway, beginning slightly north of 7th STreet, extending to the business section of Boradway, just south of 9th Street, property is occupied by original owners, who keep same in fair repair (better tahn surrounding property), and hence property in this small section is entitled to a C grade rating; a similar condition exists on bboth sides of 5th Avenue from 12th to 13th Streets. In D-3 on the western side of Pierpont Avenue, just north of Rose Hill Street, property located along the north side of 18th Street, between 12th and 14th Avenues, extending through to the osuth side of 19th Street between 13th and 14th Avenues, in the northern portion of this area, is located the community busiuness district and the Archer and Parkins Hosierymills; a small business section is located along both side of Linwood Boulevard in this area, between 10th and 13th Avenues. In D-4 on the east sideof 10th Avenue, between Wynnton Road and 12th Street is located one of the Bradley Cotton Mills.

areaDesc.2: Principal subdivisions in this area are Britt Addition, East Wynnton, Tate Survey and Wynnton & Blankenship Survey. The land is practivally level.
areaDesc.3: Proximity to Wynnton School, playgrounds, churches, and community business center. All utilities in. Adequate bus transportation.
areaDesc.4: Building restrictions only medium. Only about 20% of the streets are paved.
areaDesc.14: (a) Rental prices did not go lower because presence of Army poeple at depression low furnished stronger rental demands than would ordinarily have prevailed. Most lenders restrict their loans in this area. At the northeast corner of Lawyer's Lane and Marion Street are located one or two fine residences which are superior to the other property in the area and desrve a B rating. Also in this area, on the south side of Wynnton Road, just east of Tate Drive, area a group of Negro houses, with antoher group located on the east side of Brit Avenue, between Schaul and Marion Streets. On both sides of Francis Street, between Lawyer's Lane and Ada Avenue, are several properties whose repair condition entitles them to a D grade rating.

15.1: Mr. H. Land, of Land Realty Company, and Mr. Harry F. Boyce, of the Boyce Realty Company, who is also president of the Columbus Real Estate Board

areaDesc.2: Principal subdivisions are Rock Park, Wynnton Heights, and Boulevard Terrace (B-1); Wildwood Circle and remaining portion Woodcrest (B-3); Wynnton south of Macon Road, Oakview, and remaining portion of Overlook (B-2); Weracoba Heights (B-4); St. Elmo (B-5); Cherokee heights (B-6). Land is these areas is rolling and hilly, except in B-2) and B-5, where the land is level and sloping.
areaDesc.3: All public utilities in. About 60% of streets paved. All areas zoned and restricted. Proximity of the areas to schools, parks, play-grounds, and community business centers. All areas except B-3 and B-6 have adequate bus transportaion.
areaDesc.4: B-6 is adversely affected because of distance from schools, churches, buses, and community centers.
areaDesc.14: B-1 has about 40 houses; B-2 about 50; B-3 about 50; B-4 about 100; B-5 about 150; B-6 about 10, aming a total of approximately 400 houses in tehse 6 areas. Jumping of a color grade along the southwestern boundary of B-2 (Blue to red) is explained by the fact taht this portion of B-2 is on this top of a high hill which drops off abruptly to the adjoining negro property (d-4) below the crest of the hill. There is one large multiple unil apartment house in B-3. In the southeastern section of B-2, along both sides of Buena Vista Road, beginning at Brown Avenue and extending about 2 blocks west, are a group of properties whose poor repair condition places same in the D classification, instead of B as shown by the map; also in this same area on the northeast corner of Edgewood Drive and Benning Boulevard are one or two large properties which should be classified as C grade property. In B-3 from 16th to 17th Street east of Wildwood Avenue, are several large old properties which should be classified as C grade property

areaDesc.2: Principal subdivisions are the old portion of Wynnton and Old Wynnton Heights. The land in this area is all high, with some rolling and some level.
areaDesc.3: Community business center and restrictions in most of the area, good schools, play-ground and adequate bus transportation. All utilities in. About 90% of streets paved.
areaDesc.4: Distance from churches. Heavy traffic conditions along Wynnton Road.

5.a: Mixed, varying from business exectutives and professional men to retired Army people

areaDesc.14: (a) Less than a dozen sales occurred in this area at the low, hence difficult to fix sale values at low. This area contains heterogeneous and spotted residential property. Some of the property should receive a B grade, the location of these groups of property are on the north side of Buena Vista Road, in teh eastern portion of Dinglewood; the eastern side of 16th Avenue, from Wynnton Road to the alley north of 12th Street; and the northwest corner of Wynnton Road and Peacock Avenue. Also in this area, on the west side of Britt Avenue, midway between Wynnton Road and Schaul Street, is located the community fire station and a group of Negro rental property adjoining expensive residential property which fronts on Wynnton Road.

15.1: Mr. H. Land, of Land Realty Company, and Mr. Harry F. Boyce, of the Boyce Realty Company, who is also president of the Columbus Real Estate Board.

D2.name: Old North Highlands, North Columbus, etc.

areaDesc.2: This area contains sections known as Old North Highlands, North Columbus, Beallwood, and Beallwood heights. Majority of the land is rolling.
areaDesc.3: Proximity to churches, schools and play-grounds. Adequate bus transportation. Electricity and water in. Proximity to sources of employment for majority of area; not applicable to Beallwood and Beallwood Heights.
areaDesc.4: No zoning, but deeds contain racial restictions. Less than 3% of streets are apved. Small percentage of vandalism. Beallwood and Beallwood Heights are outside of city, hence have no city water, sewer, gas or fire protection; also have inadequate bus transportation.

g.1: Rapidly in Beallwood, but static in North Columbus and Old North Highlands

15.1: Mr. H. Land, of Land Realty Company, and Mr. Harry F. Boyrce, of the Boyce Realty Company, who is also president of the Columbus Real Estate Board

areaDesc.2: Principal subdivisions are the eastern portion of East Highlands (C-3); Delaunay Place (C-4); Wavery Terrace, and part of Rosehill Heights (C-5); Rosehill (C-6). The land is partly rolling and partly level, with the majority level.
areaDesc.3: Good schools, churches, play-grounds and bus facilities. All utilities in.
areaDesc.4: Lack of zoning and poor building restrictions in C-6; other areas only fair in this respect. Advanced age and poor repair condition of properties in C-3 to C-6, inclusive. About 40% of streets paved in these four areas.

5.e: Only in C-3 and 6 of lower income bracket
5.a: Skilled mechanics, city employees, and clerical workers

areaDesc.14: (a) Insurance companies will not lend in these areas and local lenders will only lend on a restricted basis. In C-5 many of the properties located on both sides of 10th Avenue, from 31 to 32 Streets and both sides of 32 Street, from 10th to 11th Avenues, are in such poor repair condition as to rate a D grading. A similar group of property is located at the northweat and southeast corners of 33rd Street and 12th Avenue. There is a small business section located at the intersection of River and Hamilton Roads. In C-6 there is a small business section located on Hamilton Road, from 26th to 29th Streets.

15.1: Mr. H Land, of Land Realty Company, and Mr. Harry F. Boyce, of the Boyce Realty Company, Who is also president of the Columbus Real Estate Board.

areaDesc.2: Principal subdivisions are the eastern portion of East Highlands (C-3); Delaunay Place (C-4); Wavery Terrace, and part of Rosehill Heights (C-5); Rosehill (C-6). The land is partly rolling and partly level, with the majority level.

5.e: Only in C-3 and 6 of lower income bracket
5.a: Skilled mechanics, city employees, and clerical workers

areaDesc.14: (a) Insurance companies will not lend in these areas and local lenders will only lend on a restricted basis. In C-5 many of the properties located on both sides of 10th Avenue, from 31 to 32 Streets and both sides of 32 Street, from 10th to 11th Avenues, are in such poor repair condition as to rate a D grading. A similar group of property is located at the northweat and southeast corners of 33rd Street and 12th Avenue. There is a small business section located at the intersection of River and Hamilton Roads. In C-6 there is a small business section located on Hamilton Road, from 26th to 29th Streets.

15.1: Mr. H Land, of Land Realty Company, and Mr. Harry F. Boyce, of the Boyce Realty Company, Who is also president of the Columbus Real Estate Board.

areaDesc.2: Principal subdivisions in this area are known as Evans Manor and Rosehill Heights. The land in the same is slightly rolling.
areaDesc.3: All utilities in. Moderate restrictions. Play-ground in area and new $300,000 Industrial High School, recently completed, adjoins the area on teh eastern side.
areaDesc.4: Less than 10% of thes streets are paved. Distance from community business centers, main business section of Columbus, and churches.

5.a: City employees, skilled mechanics, and clerical workers

areaDesc.13: Slightly upward temporarily on account of new school, then static later on.
areaDesc.14: (a) There are about 40 houses in this area at the present time. About 30 of same have been built since 1929 and abut 10 of this 30 have been completed since Jan. 1, 1937. In 1929 there were no paved streets in the area, which was then about 3/4 miles distant from adequate bus transportation as well as schools. Due principally to erection of the new Industrial High School, the new residential construction in the area is of a higher type than that of the residences originally built in the area and, consequently, demands a better rental price. (b) Generally speaking, insurance companies will not lend in this area, but local individual lenders, building and loan associations, and "Federals" will, although at a slightly higher rate than in the other B areas (aboput 6%).

15.1: Mr. H Land, of the Land Realty Company, and Mr. Harry F. Boyce, of the Boyce Realty Company, who is also president of the Columbus Real EState Board.

5.a: Skilled mechanics, city employees, and clerical workers

areaDesc.14: (a) Insurance companies will not lend in these areas and local lenders will only lend on a restricted basis. In C-5 many of the properties located on both sides of 10th Avenue, from 31 to 32 Streets and both sides of 32 Street, from 10th to 11th Avenues, are in such poor repair condition as to rate a D grading. A similar group of property is located at the northweat and southeast corners of 33rd Street and 12th Avenue. There is a small business section located at the intersection of River and Hamilton Roads. In C-6 there is a small business section located on Hamilton Road, from 26th to 29th Streets.

15.1: Mr. H Land, of Land Realty Company, and Mr. Harry F. Boyce, of the Boyce Realty Company, Who is also president of the Columbus Real Estate Board.

areaDesc.2: Principal subdivisions are the eastern portion of East Highlands (C-3); Delaunay Place (C-4); Wavery Terrace, and part of Rosehill Heights (C-5); Rosehill (C-6). The land is partly rolling and partly level, with the majority level.
areaDesc.3: Good schools, churches, play-grounds and bus facilities. All utilities in.
areaDesc.4: Lack of zoning and poor building restrictions in C-6; other areas only fair in this respect. Advanced age and poor repair condition of properties in C-3 to C-6, inclusive. About 40% of streets paved in these four areas.

5.e: Only in C-3 and 6 of lower income bracket
5.a: Skilled mechanics, city employees, and clerical workers

areaDesc.14: (a) Insurance companies will not lend in these areas and local lenders will only lend on a restricted basis. In C-5 many of the properties located on both sides of 10th Avenue, from 31 to 32 Streets and both sides of 32 Street, from 10th to 11th Avenues, are in such poor repair condition as to rate a D grading. A similar group of property is located at the northweat and southeast corners of 33rd Street and 12th Avenue. There is a small business section located at the intersection of River and Hamilton Roads. In C-6 there is a small business section located on Hamilton Road, from 26th to 29th Streets.

15.1: Mr. H Land, of Land Realty Company, and Mr. Harry F. Boyce, of the Boyce Realty Company, Who is also president of the Columbus Real Estate Board.

areaDesc.2: Principal subdivisions are Rock Park, Wynnton Heights, and Boulevard Terrace (B-1); Wildwood Circle and remaining portion Woodcrest (B-3); Wynnton south of Macon Road, Oakview, and remaining portion of Overlook (B-2); Weracoba Heights (B-4); St. Elmo (B-5); Cherokee heights (B-6). Land is these areas is rolling and hilly, except in B-2) and B-5, where the land is level and sloping.
areaDesc.3: All public utilities in. About 60% of streets paved. All areas zoned and restricted. Proximity of the areas to schools, parks, play-grounds, and community business centers. All areas except B-3 and B-6 have adequate bus transportaion.
areaDesc.4: B-6 is adversely affected because of distance from schools, churches, buses, and community centers.
areaDesc.14: B-1 has about 40 houses; B-2 about 50; B-3 about 50; B-4 about 100; B-5 about 150; B-6 about 10, aming a total of approximately 400 houses in tehse 6 areas. Jumping of a color grade along the southwestern boundary of B-2 (Blue to red) is explained by the fact taht this portion of B-2 is on this top of a high hill which drops off abruptly to the adjoining negro property (d-4) below the crest of the hill. There is one large multiple unil apartment house in B-3. In the southeastern section of B-2, along both sides of Buena Vista Road, beginning at Brown Avenue and extending about 2 blocks west, are a group of properties whose poor repair condition places same in the D classification, instead of B as shown by the map; also in this same area on the northeast corner of Edgewood Drive and Benning Boulevard are one or two large properties which should be classified as C grade property. In B-3 from 16th to 17th Street east of Wildwood Avenue, are several large old properties which should be classified as C grade property
